pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:0.5: 24. The training rule on worldly gain
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.2: At that time the senior monks who were instructing the nuns received robe-cloth, almsfood, dwellings, and medicinal supplies.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.3: And the monks from the group of six said this about them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.4: “The senior monks aren’t instructing the nuns as a service, but for the sake of worldly gain.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.5: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.6: “How can the monks from the group of six say that
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.7: the senior monks aren’t instructing the nuns to render a service, but for the sake of worldly gain?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.8: “Is it true, monks, that you say this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.12: “Foolish men, how can you say this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.15: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:1.16.1: ‘If a monk says that the senior monks are instructing the nuns for the sake of worldly gain, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.1.5: For the sake of worldly gain:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.1.6: for the sake of robe-cloth, for the sake of almsfood, for the sake of a dwelling, for the sake of medicinal supplies, for the sake of honor, for the sake of respect, for the sake of deference, for the sake of veneration, for the sake of worship.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.1.8: if, concerning one who is fully ordained and who has been appointed by the Sangha as an instructor of nuns—desiring to disparage him, desiring to give him a bad reputation, desiring to humiliate him—he says, “He instructs for the sake of robe-cloth,” “… for the sake of almsfood,” “… for the sake of a dwelling,” “… for the sake of medicinal supplies,” “… for the sake of honor,” “… for the sake of respect,” “… for the sake of deference,” “… for the sake of veneration,” “… for the sake of worship,” he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.1: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, and he says such a thing, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.2: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, and he says such a thing, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.3: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as illegitimate, and he says such a thing, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.4: When someone who is fully ordained is an instructor of nuns, but he has not been appointed by the Sangha as such, and a monk—desiring to disparage him, desiring to give him a bad reputation, desiring to humiliate him—says,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.5: “He instructs for the sake of robe-cloth,” “… for the sake of almsfood,” “… for the sake of a dwelling,” “… for the sake of medicines,” “… for the sake of honor,” “… for the sake of respect,” “… for the sake of deference,” “… for the sake of veneration,” “… for the sake of worship,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.6: When someone who is not fully ordained is an instructor of nuns, whether or not he has been appointed by the Sangha as such, and a monk—desiring to disparage him, desiring to give him a bad reputation, desiring to humiliate him—says,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.7: “He instructs for the sake of robe-cloth,” “… for the sake of almsfood,” “… for the sake of a dwelling,” “… for the sake of medicinal supplies,” “… for the sake of honor,” “… for the sake of respect,” “… for the sake of deference,” “… for the sake of veneration,” “… for the sake of worship,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.8: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as legitimate, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.9: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.2.10: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.3.2: if he says it to one who regularly gives the instruction for the sake of robe-cloth, … for the sake of almsfood, … for the sake of a dwelling, … for the sake of medicinal supplies, … for the sake of honor, … for the sake of respect, … for the sake of deference, … for the sake of veneration, … for the sake of worship;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.3.4: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc24:2.3.5: The training rule on worldly gain, the fourth, is finished.
